title: 115_hr4175
content: The "Invest in Innovative Small Businesses Act" includes an Angel Investment Tax Credit under section 30E of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax credit allows a 25 percent credit for qualified equity investments made by a qualified investor in a small business entity. Qualified equity investment is defined as an equity investment acquired at original issue solely for cash and designated by the small business entity. Equity investment includes any form of equity. The tax credit allows a 25 percent credit for qualified equity investments in a small business entity. Qualified equity investment is any form of equity, including partnership interests and capital interests. The term 'qualified small business entity' refers to a domestic corporation or partnership that is a small business, headquartered in the United States, and engaged in high technology trades or businesses related to advanced materials, aerospace, biotechnology, electronics, energy, or clean technologies. The term 'qualified small business entity' refers to a domestic corporation or partnership that is a small business, headquartered in the United States, and engaged in high technology trades or businesses related to various sectors such as forest products, agriculture, information technology, communication technology, life sciences, marine technology, transportation, or any other high technology trade as determined by the Secretary. The business must have been in existence for less than 5 years, employ less than 100 full-time equivalent employees, and have more than 50 percent of its employees. For purposes of this paragraph, a qualified small business entity must have more than 50 percent of employees working in the United States and designated equity investments not exceeding $10,000,000 in total. The text chunk discusses the criteria for qualified equity investments made by taxpayers, with specific dollar amounts for individuals and groups. It also defines a qualified investor as an accredited investor or investor network reviewing potential businesses for investment. The curr_chunk discusses an investor fund, defined as a group of accredited investors organized to make qualified equity investments. The fund can be structured as an S corporation, partnership, trust, or LLC, and the tax credit is allocated to shareholders or partners based on their ownership interest. The curr_chunk explains that tax-exempt investors can transfer their interest in the fund to other investors for future financial consideration. If the investor fund is a single-member LLC disregarded as a separate entity, the tax credit can be claimed by the owner subject to tax. The term 'qualified investor' excludes individuals controlling 50% of the small business, employees of the entity, and certain financial institutions. There is a $500,000,000 angel investment tax credit limitation for each year from 2018 to 2022, allocated by the Secretary. The Secretary allocates paragraph (1) among qualified small business entities. Any excess in the angel investment tax credit limitation for a year carries over to the next year. The credit is treated as part of the general business credit. The credit allowed under subsection (a) for any taxable year shall be treated as a credit allowable under subpart A for such taxable year, with limitations based on the amount of tax. The credit allowable under subsection (a) can be carried forward for up to 20 taxable years if it exceeds the limitation imposed by section 26(a)(1) or subparagraph (B), reduced by other credits allowable under subpart A for the taxable year. The credit under subsection (a) can be carried forward for up to 20 taxable years if it exceeds the limitation imposed by section 26(a)(1) or subparagraph (B), reduced by other credits. Related parties are treated as one person, and the basis of any investment for which a credit is allowable is reduced by the credit amount. The credit under subsection (a) can be carried forward for up to 20 taxable years if it exceeds the limitation imposed by section 26(a)(1) or subparagraph (B), reduced by other credits. Related parties are treated as one person, and the basis of any investment for which a credit is allowable is reduced by the credit amount. The recapture of the benefit of any credit allowable under subsection (a) is provided for by the Secretary in cases where a qualified equity investment is held for less than 3 years, with exceptions for certain transfers like those due to death, between spouses, incident to divorce, or under section 381(a) transactions. This subsection does not apply to sections 1202, 1397B, and 1400B. The Secretary will prescribe regulations to prevent abuse, impose reporting requirements, and apply provisions to newly formed entities. The angel investment tax credit is added to the general business credit under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The angel investment tax credit is incorporated into the general business credit under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, with amendments made to section 1016(a) and the addition of a new paragraph (38) in relation to section 30E(g)(2). The angel investment tax credit, under section 30E, applies to investments made after December 31, 2017. Regulations on allocation of the national limitation must be prescribed within 120 days of the enactment of the Act. This includes criteria for determining allocations to small business entities. The Secretary or delegate shall ensure proper allocations to qualified small business entities, considering factors such as angel investment tax credits, allocations to different population density States, and receipt of federal grants. The Comptroller General will audit and report on the angel investment tax credit program by January 31, 2021, including allocations to qualified small business entities.
